questions.text: What does the Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) measure?  (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anisocytosis

 

Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) is a measure of the variation in red blood cell (RBC) size. Anisocytosis, which is the variation in the sizes of RBCs, is directly assessed by RDW. A higher RDW indicates a greater variation in size. RDW is used clinically to help differentiate between types of anemia and to provide insight into the underlying mechanisms of anemia. Normal RDW values range from 11-14%.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypochromia: Refers to RBCs having less color than normal, indicative of less hemoglobin content per cell, not directly related to RDW.

 

Option C. Poikilocytosis: Indicates variation in the shape of RBCs, not their size, hence not directly assessed by RDW.

 

Option D. Anisochromia: Refers to variation in hemoglobin content among RBCs, which is not measured by RDW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RDW measures the variability in size of red blood cells, which is indicative of anisocytosis. High RDW is associated with conditions like iron deficiency anemia and other types of anemia, where there is significant variation in RBC sizes.

 

Additional Information

 

IDA vs Thalassemia

 

IDA- rbcs are small (low MCV ) with high RDW

 

Thalassemia- RBCs are small (low MCV )  with normal RDW

questions.text: A patient is a known case of hypertension and is on multiple antihypertensive drugs. His ECG is shown below. Which drug is responsible for the following ECG? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Spironolactone

 

The ECG shows tall, tented T waves, absent P waves (atrial standstill), and a severely widened QRS complex. These are classic signs of severe hyperkalemia.

 

Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that can cause hyperkalemia. It is known for increasing potassium levels in the blood by inhibiting the effects of aldosterone, leading to decreased excretion of potassium in the urine.

 

Therefore, the drug most likely responsible for the ECG findings is Spironolactone due to its potent potassium-sparing effects leading to severe hyperkalemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: Causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Metoprolol: Can cause mild hyperkalemia but not to the extent seen in the ECG.

 

Option D. Prazosin: Does not affect potassium levels significantly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Spironolactone, a potassium-sparing diuretic, can cause severe hyperkalemia, which is characterized by tall, tented T waves, absent P waves, and widened QRS complexes on an ECG.

choices.text: Chest compression to Rescue breath ratio is 30:2

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding High-Quality CPR?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Depth of compression must be 3-4cm

 

The statement "Depth of compression must be 3-4cm" is incorrect for high-quality CPR. The correct depth of chest compression for adults is approximately 5 centimeters (or 2 inches). This depth ensures adequate blood flow during cardiopulmonary resuscitation. The 3-4cm depth mentioned in the option is insufficient for effective CPR in adults.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest compressions at 100-120/min: This is correct. The recommended rate for chest compressions during CPR is 100-120 compressions per minute. This rate optimizes blood flow during resuscitation efforts.

 

Option B. Allow adequate chest recoil: This statement is correct. Allowing full chest recoil between compressions is crucial for effective CPR. It enables proper diastolic filling of the heart, improving overall circulation.

 

Option C. Chest compression to Rescue breath ratio is 30:2: This is also correct. For adult CPR without an advanced airway, the standard ratio is 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In high-quality CPR for adults, the correct depth of chest compressions is approximately 5 centimeters (2 inches), not 3-4cm as stated in the incorrect option.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

 

The substantia nigra is the marked structure in the transverse section of the brain that is shown. Degeneration of the substantia nigra is observed in Parkinson's disease, commonly referred to as paralysis agitans.

 

Due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which aid in the manufacture of dopamine, the substantia nigra is pigmented. The substantia nigra lacks or has less pigmentation in Parkinson's disease.

 

Parkinson's disease is characterized by bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors. It's also known as paralysis agitans due to the motor dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Depression: Incorrect because depression is typically associated with dysfunctions in other brain regions such as the prefrontal cortex and limbic system, not specifically the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Alzheimer’s disease: Incorrect as Alzheimer's disease primarily involves the cerebral cortex and hippocampus, leading to amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, rather than specific damage to the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Huntington chorea: Incorrect because Huntington’s disease involves degeneration of the striatum and other parts of the brain but does not primarily affect the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with skin thickening muscle weakness and the peripheries becoming pale on exposure to cold. She is positive for ANA and anti-Scl-70 antibodies. Her creatinine kinase is elevated and muscle biopsy shows perifascicular infiltration. What is the antibody associated with this? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anti-PM-Scl antibody

 

The patient presents with features of scleroderma and dermatomyositis overlap syndrome. Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with this overlap syndrome, tends to produce nucleolar pattern in your ANA immunofluorescence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-U3 RNP: Associated with the diffuse form of scleroderma and are also known as anti-fibrillarin antibodies.
 

Option B. Anti-centromere antibody: Associated with limited scleroderma (CREST syndrome).
 

Option D. Anti-Jo-1 antibody: Associated with antisynthetase syndrome, which predominantly causes interstitial lung disease (ILD), mechanic's hands, myositis, and Raynaud's phenomenon. It is not associated with scleroderma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-PM-Scl antibody is associated with overlap syndromes involving scleroderma and myositis.

questions.text: Calculate the GCS Score in an intubated patient, with findings of eye movements to pain and abnormal flexion? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) E2VNTM3.

 

The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score is used to assess the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury and other conditions. In this scenario, the patient is intubated, which affects the ability to assess the verbal response. The current nomenclature for denoting non-testability due to intubation is "NT" (Non-testable) for the verbal component.

 

  • Eye Opening (E): The patient opens eyes in response to painful stimuli, which scores 2.
  • Verbal Response (V): The verbal component is non-testable (NT) due to intubation.
  • Motor Response (M): The patient exhibits abnormal flexion (decorticate response), which scores 3.

 

This combination gives a GCS score of E2VNTM3.

 

 

NT = non-testability of the corresponding component.

 

Used mainly in acute TBI (Traumatic brain injury).

 

Update:

 

1. GCS-P Score takes pupillary activity into consideration.

 

P = Pupillary non-reactivity

 

2 = Both pupil

 

1 = One pupil

 

0 = None

 

Minimum = 1, Max = 15.

 

2. FOUR score (Full outline of unresponsiveness) is currently employed having better sensitivity, specificity and PPV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In intubated patients, the GCS verbal score is marked as "NT" for non-testable. The GCS remains a vital tool in assessing the level of consciousness, particularly in emergency and critical care settings, ensuring that changes in the patient’s neurological status are promptly recognized and appropriately managed.

 

Reference - Harrison/Neurology/Basics /Chapter 443-TBI

choices.text: Lifestyle modification and weight loss
Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification
Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E
Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications

questions.text: A patient with a history of consumption of 2-3 drinks per week comes with complaints of right upper quadrant discomfort. He has grade 2 steatosis. His BMI was 29 kg/m² and AST and ALT levels were slightly elevated. What would you advise him? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lifestyle modification and weight loss

 

Explanation:  

 

The patient is likely suffering from non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD), specifically non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), given his history of minimal alcohol consumption, grade 2 steatosis, elevated BMI, and mildly elevated liver enzymes (AST and ALT). The cornerstone of treatment for NASH is lifestyle modification and weight loss. These interventions help reduce liver fat, inflammation, and fibrosis. No FDA-approved medications currently exist for the treatment of NASH; thus, lifestyle changes are the primary recommended approach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ursodeoxycholic acid and lifestyle modification: Ursodeoxycholic acid is used for primary biliary cholangitis, not NASH, and thus is not appropriate here.

 

Option C. Lifestyle modifications and vitamin E: Vitamin E can be used off-label in non-diabetic patients with NASH but is not FDA-approved or considered first-line treatment. It can be considered but is secondary to lifestyle changes.

 

Option D. Pioglitazone and lifestyle modifications: Pioglitazone, along with other medications like metformin and GLP-1 receptor agonists, is sometimes used off-label for diabetic patients with NASH. However, it is not FDA-approved for NASH and should not be the first-line recommendation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lifestyle modification and weight loss are the primary and most effective treatments for non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH), as no FDA-approved medications are currently available for this condition.

questions.text: A 65-year-old lady presented to the casualty with Hb - 5.4 g/dL, urea-86 mg/dL, creatinine- 6 mg/dL, calcium - 12 mg/dL, potassium - 4.4 mEq/L. Bone marrow aspiration shows > 60% of plasma cells. What is the next line of management? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone + Fluids

 

Features are suggestive of Multiple myeloma presenting with Mild Hypercalcemia with no pulmonary edema. Hence, treatment with steroids and IV fluids are recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dialysis is recommended if Hyperkalemia, Pulmonary edema, refractory acidosis, and Uremia.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone + lenalidomide is recommended in definitive therapy for MM along with bortezomib +/- Daratumumab (Anti CD38).

 

Option D. Bone marrow transplant is considered upfront in high-risk disease as definitive therapy.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Immediate management of a newly diagnosed multiple myeloma patient presenting with anemia, renal failure, and hypercalcemia should prioritize rapid medical intervention to stabilize the patient. This includes hydration and the use of steroids to reduce plasma cell proliferation and calcium levels. Subsequent treatments will be based on the patient’s response and overall treatment strategy.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/Plasma cell dyscrasia/Chap 111

choices.text: Fasciculation at the level of lesion
Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion

questions.text: Which of the following does not help in the localization of lesions in the spinal cord? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contralateral hemiplegia

 

When localizing lesions in the spinal cord, it is crucial to understand how different tracts and their associated functions are affected:

 

  1. Corticospinal Tract: Damage to this tract results in ipsilateral hemiparesis (weakness) below the level of the lesion. This is because the corticospinal tract crosses over (decussates) at the medulla, above the spinal cord. Therefore, damage at the spinal cord level affects the same side of the body.
  2. Posterior Column: Damage here leads to ipsilateral loss of light touch, vibration, proprioception, and pressure. Similar to the corticospinal tract, the posterior column pathways decussate above the spinal cord.
  3. Spinothalamic Tract: This tract, responsible for pain and temperature sensation, crosses at the level of the spinal cord itself. Damage to the spinothalamic tract results in contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation.

 

Given these pathways, contralateral hemiplegia suggests a lesion above the spinal cord, typically above the pyramidal decussation in the brainstem or higher. Therefore, it does not help in localizing lesions within the spinal cord itself.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fasciculation at the level of lesion: Fasciculations are a sign of lower motor neuron involvement, which can occur at the level of the spinal cord lesion due to damage to the anterior horn cells. This helps in localizing the lesion.

 

Option C. Upper motor neuron lesion and lower motor neuron lesion: The presence of both upper motor neuron (UMN) and lower motor neuron (LMN) signs can be indicative of a spinal cord lesion. UMN signs (such as spasticity and hyperreflexia) occur below the lesion, while LMN signs (such as fasciculations and muscle atrophy) occur at the level of the lesion.

 

Option D. Bladder involvement: Bladder and bowel dysfunction are common in transverse spinal cord lesions. This is due to the involvement of the autonomic pathways that control these functions, helping to localize the lesion within the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Contralateral hemiplegia indicates a lesion above the spinal cord, specifically above the level of pyramidal decussation.

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of >180/95 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

 

An early diastolic murmur in the right 2nd intercostal space is suggestive of aortic regurgitation. Supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely to be associated with the above findings.

 

BP difference between arms is classical due to blood jet projected towards right brachiocephalic artery, but the murmur of AR is very rare.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Coarctation of the Aorta: Can sometimes show differences in arm blood pressures, especially if the coarctation is proximal to the left subclavian artery. It is also associated with a bicuspid aortic valve, which can lead to AR.

 

Option C. Takayasu Arteritis: Known for causing vascular inflammation leading to stenoses, which can result in differing blood pressures in the arms. About 25% of patients may also have AR.

 

Option D. Aortic Dissection: Typically presents with differential blood pressure between arms and can rapidly lead to AR due to involvement of the aortic root.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While differential arm blood pressure can suggest several cardiovascular anomalies, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely among the options given to be associated with these findings, especially concerning the presence of a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation.

choices.text: Vancomycin and Gentamicin
Meropenem and Linezolid
Cotrimoxazole with Ceftazidime

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of cystic fibrosis presents with high-grade fevers, chills, and progressive shortness of breath. He has been experiencing worsening symptoms over the past week. Blood cultures grow Burkholderia cepacia, and a transesophageal echocardiogram reveals vegetations on the mitral valve consistent with infective endocarditis. What is the most appropriate first-line management for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cotrimoxazole with Ceftazidime

 

Explanation:

 

Burkholderia cepacia is a challenging pathogen to treat, particularly in individuals with cystic fibrosis or those presenting with infective endocarditis. The standard first-line therapy includes a combination of cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) with an anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam such as ceftazidime. This regimen targets Burkholderia cepacia effectively due to its synergistic antimicrobial action and has shown success in reducing morbidity and complications associated with the infection. Ceftazidime provides broad-spectrum coverage against gram-negative organisms, while cotrimoxazole is specifically effective against Burkholderia species.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Vancomycin and Gentamicin: This combination is typically used for gram-positive organisms, including staphylococcal species. It is not effective against Burkholderia cepacia, which is inherently resistant to many standard antibiotics, making this regimen inappropriate.

 

Option B) Meropenem and Linezolid: While meropenem is a broad-spectrum beta-lactam that covers many resistant gram-negative bacteria, it is not reliably effective against Burkholderia cepacia. Linezolid is primarily used for resistant gram-positive infections and does not provide adequate coverage for Burkholderia.

 

Option D) Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic combination is commonly used for community-acquired infections but lacks efficacy against Burkholderia cepacia due to its intrinsic resistance. It is not suitable for treating severe infections like endocarditis caused by this pathogen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burkholderia cepacia is a multidrug-resistant pathogen, often requiring combination therapy for effective treatment. The first-line regimen for Burkholderia cepacia infections, including endocarditis, is cotrimoxazole with ceftazidime, which targets the pathogen effectively and is crucial for managing severe infections associated with this organism. Recognizing appropriate antibiotic choices is essential for treating infections caused by resistant bacteria

choices.text: Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen.
Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus.
Palpation begins at the site of pain.
Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation.

questions.text: A patient presents with severe abdominal pain. Identify the false statement given about the examination of the abdomen: (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Palpation begins at the site of pain.

 

Palpation in the examination of a patient with abdominal pain should never start at the site of pain. Instead, it should begin away from the painful area to avoid causing the patient unnecessary discomfort and to prevent muscle guarding that might obscure findings. This approach allows the examiner to gather information about the non-painful areas first and approach the painful site last, ensuring a more accurate and less distressing examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hemoperitoneum leads to reddish discoloration of the flanks of the abdomen: This statement is correct. Hemoperitoneum, which is bleeding into the peritoneal cavity, can cause reddish or purplish discoloration on the flanks, known as Grey Turner’s sign. This is a significant indicator of internal bleeding, particularly in cases of acute pancreatitis or trauma.

 

Option B. Cullen’s sign refers to discoloration around the umbilicus: This statement is correct. Cullen’s sign is the appearance of bluish discoloration around the umbilicus, which indicates intraperitoneal hemorrhage. It is often associated with conditions such as ruptured ectopic pregnancy or acute pancreatitis.

 

Option D. Guarding and rigidity indicate peritoneal irritation: This statement is correct. Guarding (voluntary or involuntary muscle contraction) and rigidity (a constant, board-like hardness of the abdominal muscles) are classic signs of peritoneal irritation or inflammation, such as that seen in peritonitis. These signs suggest that there may be an underlying acute inflammatory or infectious process in the abdomen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When examining a patient with abdominal pain, always begin palpation away from the site of pain to ensure a more accurate and less distressing assessment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with substernal chest discomfort. On examination, he was hypotensive, drowsy, and had unequal pulses. Which of the following investigations would be the best in this situation to ascertain the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trans-esophageal echocardiography

 

The presentation of acute chest pain, hypotension, drowsiness, and unequal pulses strongly suggests aortic dissection. Aortic dissection is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate diagnosis and management.

 

Trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosing aortic dissection. It can be performed at the bedside, making it ideal for unstable patients. TEE provides detailed images of the aorta and can quickly confirm the presence of an intimal flap, a characteristic finding in aortic dissection.

 

If the patient has been stable, then preferred investigation of choice is CT angiography.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CXR PA view: A chest X-ray (CXR) might show a widened mediastinum, which can be a clue to aortic dissection, but it is not definitive. It lacks the sensitivity and specificity needed for a rapid and accurate diagnosis in an emergency setting.

 

Option C. MRI: While MRI can provide excellent detail, it is not suitable for acutely unstable patients due to the time required for the scan and the need to transport the patient to the MRI suite. It is not practical in an emergency setting.

 

Option D. Troponin assay: Troponin assays are used to diagnose myocardial infarction, not aortic dissection. Although troponins can be elevated in some cases of aortic dissection, they do not provide definitive diagnostic information about the dissection itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the setting of suspected aortic dissection, especially in an unstable patient, trans-esophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the best diagnostic tool due to its high sensitivity and ability to be performed at the bedside, providing rapid and accurate confirmation of the diagnosis.

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings: Hb - 6.9g/dL, WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count, Serum calcium 13mg/dL, Creatinine 2.3mg/dL, Total protein 9g/dL, Albumin 2.4g/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

The patient's symptoms, combined with lab findings of anemia, hypercalcemia, elevated total protein, and low albumin, along with osteolytic lesions, are indicative of multiple myeloma. The CRAB criteria (hyperCalcemia, Renal failure, Anemia, and Bone lesions) support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:


 

Option A. Metastatic breast cancer can present similarly but usually has a different primary site.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism causes hypercalcemia but not the full CRAB criteria.

 

Option D. Milk Alkali Syndrome causes hypercalcemia and renal impairment but not the protein abnormalities or osteolytic lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by anemia, hypercalcemia, renal failure, and bone lesions.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male admitted to the ICU for acute exacerbation of COPD develops a sudden onset of palpitations. The following ECG changes are seen. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Multifocal atrial tachycardia             

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. VT is usually regular and wide QRS tachycardia (QRS > 120ms).

 

Option B. P waves usually absent in AF.

 

Option D. Atrial tachycardia is regular narrow QRS tachycardia with fixed morphology of P wave.

 

Note:

 

  • MAT is usually associated with lung disease and occurs secondary to underlying hypoxemia.
  • Treatment is with CCB > BB to slow the atrial, ventricular rate.
  • Cardioversion is ineffective and contraindicated in this rhythm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia is characterized by multiple ectopic atrial activities leading to variable P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm, often associated with underlying chronic pulmonary conditions. Management focuses on treating the underlying condition and stabilizing the rate with appropriate medications.

 

Reference - Harrison 21E/chap 250/7033

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Subcutaneous sumatriptan

 

Subcutaneous sumatriptan is shown to be effective in treating acute attacks of cluster headaches. The reference indicates that oral sumatriptan is not effective, whereas subcutaneous sumatriptan has been proven beneficial. Intranasal sumatriptan and intranasal zolmitriptan also are shown to be effective.

 

Additionally, 100% oxygen therapy at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute is effective.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral sumatriptan: Oral sumatriptan has not been shown to be effective in treating acute cluster headache attacks.

 

Option C. 100% oxygen at 6 L/minute: Although 100% oxygen is a treatment option, the effective rate is at least 12 liters per minute, making 6 L/minute inadequate.

 

Option D. 100% oxygen at 8 L/minute: Similar to the previous option, 8 L/minute is below the effective rate of 12 liters per minute required for treating acute cluster headaches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is subcutaneous sumatriptan, and 100% oxygen therapy should be administered at a rate of at least 12 liters per minute for effectiveness.

questions.text: A patient of hemophilia received multiple blood transfusions. Which of the following metabolic abnormalities can be seen in a patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic Alkalosis

 

Metabolic alkalosis in a patient who received multiple blood transfusions arises primarily from the metabolism of citrate, used as a preservative in stored blood products.

 

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

 

Excess citrate preservative gets converted to bicarbonate causing Metabolic alkalosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic Acidosis: This condition would typically result from an accumulation of acids or loss of bicarbonate, which is not a direct consequence of blood transfusion.

 

Option C. Respiratory Alkalosis: Would involve hyperventilation leading to decreased carbon dioxide levels, unrelated to transfusion effects.

 

Option D. Respiratory Acidosis: Involves hypoventilation increasing carbon dioxide levels, which is also unrelated to the effects of blood transfusions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic alkalosis is a potential complication of multiple or massive blood transfusions due to the metabolism of citrate preservative into bicarbonate, emphasizing the importance of monitoring electrolytes and acid-base balance during such procedures.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Delayed complications: GVHD, PTP, Infections

questions.text: A patient comes with palpitation to ER. His Pulse-180/min and BP-70mm of Hg systolic. ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with regular heart rate. What is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) DC cardioversion

 

For a patient presenting with hemodynamically unstable symptoms such as a significantly low blood pressure and a high heart rate, as indicated by a pulse of 180/min and systolic BP of 70 mmHg, immediate DC cardioversion is indicated. This procedure is critical for restoring normal heart rhythm and preventing further cardiovascular compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valsalva Maneuver: it is typically used in stable patients to attempt cardioversion of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) back to a normal rhythm. It is not suitable for patients showing signs of hemodynamic instability.

 

Option C. Adenosine: it is effective in terminating certain types of SVT by temporarily blocking the AV node but is used in stable patients. Given the patient's low BP, this is not the first-line approach.

 

Option D. Verapamil: it is a calcium channel blocker used for rate control in cases of SVT, more appropriate for stable patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DC cardioversion is the emergency treatment of choice for a patient with hemodynamically unstable narrow QRS complex tachycardia, as it quickly restores normal rhythm and stabilizes the patient.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Cardiology/SVT/chap 246

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient who is a known case of COPD presented with acute exacerbation and in type 2 respiratory failure was admitted to the ICU. Which of the following statements is correct with regards to the initial management of this patient? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Non-Invasive PPV should be given

 

Non-Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (NIPPV) is often the initial treatment of choice for patients with COPD who present with an acute exacerbation and are in type 2 respiratory failure (characterized by hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis). NIPPV can improve gas exchange and reduce the work of breathing without the need for endotracheal intubation, thereby decreasing the risk of infection and other complications associated with invasive mechanical ventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Invasive Positive Pressure Ventilation (IPPV): This is generally reserved for patients who fail NIPPV or present with severe acidosis, hemodynamic instability, or decreased level of consciousness that precludes the use of NIPPV.

 

Option C. IV corticosteroids: While systemic corticosteroids are commonly used in the management of acute COPD exacerbations, the initial focus in a patient in respiratory failure should be on stabilizing the patient's breathing and gas exchange. Corticosteroids can be administered orally or intravenously, but this would not be the primary concern in the immediate management.

 

Note - Oral steroids (prednisolone) is given for 5-14 days in acute exacerbations.

 

Option D. Permissive hypercapnia: This is a strategy used in mechanical ventilation where slightly elevated levels of carbon dioxide (hypercapnia) are tolerated to avoid high ventilatory pressures that can lead to lung injury, however pH is maintained above 7.3. It is applicable during mechanical ventilation if it becomes necessary but is not an initial management step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a COPD patient presenting with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure, non-invasive ventilation is the preferred initial management strategy to stabilize the patient's respiratory status, reducing the need for intubation and potentially improving clinical outcomes.

 

Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/COPD/chapter 292

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was found unconscious at a bus stop and brought to the emergency department by paramedics. On arrival, he exhibited confusion, an altered state of consciousness, and frequent vomiting. His vital signs included a blood pressure of 85/60 mm Hg, heart rate of 105/min, temperature of 36.2°C, and a respiratory rate of 10/min. Upon physical examination, the patient presented with bilateral constricted pupils. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D. Opiate overdose

 

Explanation:

 

The patient’s symptoms, including pinpoint pupils, low blood pressure, slow respiratory rate, and altered consciousness, strongly suggest opiate overdose. Opiates depress the central nervous system, leading to reduced respiratory rate, hypotension, and characteristic miosis (pinpoint pupils).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brainstem hemorrhage: This condition typically presents with pinpoint pupils but is usually accompanied by other neurological signs such as quadriplegia and hyperreflexia.

 

Option B. Severe hypothermia: While hypothermia can cause altered sensorium, it usually presents with shivering and a lower body temperature, not necessarily pinpoint pupils.

 

Option C. Atropine toxicity: This causes dilated pupils (mydriasis) rather than pinpoint pupils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recognize that pinpoint pupils, along with decreased respiratory rate and hypotension, are hallmark indicators of opiate overdose, requiring immediate medical intervention.

choices.text: Chest wall neuromuscular disease
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: The given image shows a normal graph on the left and the patient's graph on the right. Which of the following diagnoses can be inferred from the graph? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

Explanation:  

 

The spirometry graph compares a normal patient's lung function with that of the patient. The normal graph shows an FEV1/FVC ratio (Forced Expiratory Volume in 1 second / Forced Vital Capacity) of more than 70%, which is typical in healthy individuals. In contrast, the patient's graph shows a significantly reduced FEV1/FVC ratio of approximately 50-55%, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

 

Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by reduced airflow due to airway narrowing or obstruction, leading to a lower FEV1/FVC ratio. The common obstructive lung diseases include asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, COPD, bronchiectasis, and cystic fibrosis. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the only obstructive lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest wall neuromuscular disease: This typically causes restrictive lung disease, not obstructive, and would present with a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio but reduced lung volumes.

 

Option B. Sarcoidosis: This is an interstitial lung disease, which is restrictive. It would show a normal or elevated FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced lung volumes.

 

Option C. Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis: Another interstitial lung disease leading to restrictive patterns on spirometry, characterized by a normal or high FEV1/FVC ratio with reduced total lung capacity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A reduced FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%) is indicative of obstructive lung disease. Among the given options, bronchiectasis is the obstructive lung disease associated with this spirometry pattern.

questions.text: A patient with diabetes develops a UTI, which gets complicated with hypotension that is resistant to IV fluids. Which of the following antibiotics can be used? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Piperacillin-Tazobactam

 

The patient with diabetes has developed a urinary tract infection (UTI) complicated by hypotension resistant to IV fluids, indicating septic shock. In cases of septic shock, it is critical to start with empirical broad-spectrum antibiotics. These antibiotics are designed to cover a wide range of potential pathogens until the specific causative organism can be identified and targeted.

 

Broad-spectrum antibiotics suitable for such severe infections include:

 

  • Piperacillin-Tazobactam
  • Carbapenems like Meropenem or Imipenem
  • Certain third-generation cephalosporins like Ceftazidime

 

In this case, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is chosen because it is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that covers many of the common pathogens responsible for severe infections and septic shock. Although a combination of Meropenem with Vancomycin would be ideal, the given options do not include Meropenem. Therefore, Piperacillin-Tazobactam is the best choice among the provided options.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin-Clavulanate: This antibiotic is generally not sufficient for treating severe infections or septic shock due to its narrower spectrum of activity compared to Piperacillin-Tazobactam.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: While Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, it is not as broad-spectrum as Ceftazidime and does not provide the same coverage needed for septic shock.

 

Option D. Nitrofurantoin: This antibiotic is typically used for uncomplicated lower urinary tract infections and is not effective for severe systemic infections or septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of septic shock, especially in a patient with diabetes and complicated UTI, broad-spectrum antibiotics such as Piperacillin-Tazobactam are critical for empirical therapy.

choices.text: Joint pains with nodules on skin

questions.text: A 32-year-old female with history of back ache and polyarthralgia was investigated and found to have nucleolar pattern in IF. Which of the following is the best fit in her case? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly

 

Nucleolar pattern refers to the presence of a few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represents antibodies to RNA. This pattern is reported most often in patients with systemic sclerosis. Hence, Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly will be seen.

 

 

Systemic sclerosis is more common in middle-aged women. The clinical manifestations include:

 

  • Claw-like flexion deformity of hands
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon - manifested as episodic vasoconstriction of the arteries and arterioles of the extremities, is seen in virtually all patients and precedes other symptoms in 70% of cases
  • Esophageal fibrosis causing dysphagia and hypomotility
  • Malabsorption syndrome
  • Respiratory distress due to pulmonary fibrosis
  • Malignant hypertension
  • Pulmonary hypertension
  • Biliary cirrhosis.

 

Other IF Patterns: -

 

Examples of ICAP-classified IIFA staining patterns:

 

 

 

ENA: Extractable nuclear antigens; RNP; ribonucleoproteins; SLE; systemic lupus erythematous; MCTD: mixed connective tissue disease; PM: polymyositis; dsDNA: double-stranded deoxyribonucleic acid; CENP: centromere protein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Genital and oral painful ulcers: These are more characteristic of Behçet's disease, which is associated with HLA-B51 and presents with recurrent oral and genital ulcers, uveitis, and other systemic symptoms, not a nucleolar pattern on IF.

 

Option C. Glomerulonephritis and heart failure: These features are more consistent with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which may show a different pattern on IF, such as a homogenous or peripheral (rim) pattern, rather than the nucleolar pattern associated with systemic sclerosis.

 

Option D. Joint pains with nodules on skin: This description is typical of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with rheumatoid nodules and not the nucleolar pattern seen in systemic sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The nucleolar pattern in IF is most often associated with systemic sclerosis, a condition characterized by Raynaud phenomenon and sclerodactyly, among other systemic manifestations.

 

Ref: Robbin and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Page No. 405, 425

questions.text: A 56-year-old chronic smoker presented with complaints of weight loss and cough for more than 1 year. He also has hypercalcemia. His biopsy report revealed hyperchromatic atypical cells. Which of the following is the most likely cancer is this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Squamous cell cancer

 

The presence of hyperchromatic atypical cells on biopsy with the given clinical history suggests a cancer. The history of chronic smoking with hypercalcemia as a paraneoplastic syndrome is a finding of squamous cell cancer (SCC) of the lung.  Hence, the answer is option “b”.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Small cell cancer: Often associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) and Cushing's syndrome, not typically hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Large cell neuroendocrine tumor: Less common, may have neuroendocrine features but not specifically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Adenocarcinoma: More common in non-smokers and often presents with peripheral lung lesions. Not typically associated with hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly associated with smoking and can present with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTHrP production, alongside symptoms such as chronic cough and weight loss.

questions.text: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MRSA

 

Contact-based isolation precautions are specifically employed for managing patients who are infected with or are carriers of MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). MRSA is known for its ability to spread via direct contact with infected or colonized individuals, or indirectly through contact with contaminated surfaces and objects. This isolation strategy involves using personal protective equipment, such as gloves and gowns, when interacting with the patient, and applying rigorous hygiene practices to prevent the spread of the bacterium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria: While also a communicable disease, it primarily requires droplet-based isolation due to its transmission through respiratory droplets.

 

Option C. Mumps: Similar to diphtheria, mumps is spread through respiratory droplets and thus requires droplet precautions.

 

Option D. Asthma: Not an infectious disease; it is a chronic respiratory condition that does not require transmission-based precautions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The three categories of transmission-based precautions include:

 

  • Contact- based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, VRE, diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and RSV.
  • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps.
  • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

choices.text: Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase
Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity
Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors
Increased in activity of hepatic lipase

questions.text: The value of TG and VLDL are high in chronic diabetes because of which of the following reasons: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased activity of hormone sensitive lipase and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity.

 

In chronic diabetes, increase in hormone sensitive lipase and decrease in lipoprotein is seen, due to which values of TG and VLDL are increased.

 

Insulin has inhibitory effect on hormone sensitive lipase. In diabetes, low insulin corresponds to an increase in hormone sensitive lipase activity. This promotes breakdown of lipids and release of TG, and free fatty acids from the adipose tissue.

 

Insulin induces the activity of lipoprotein lipase, which is present on capillary walls. LPL promotes hydrolysis of TG and degradation of transport proteins, VLDL and chylomicrons. In diabetes, low insulin leads to decreased LPL activity which corresponds to increase in VLDL and TG.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased activity of lipoprotein lipase and decreased activity of hormone sensitive lipase: Incorrect because in diabetes, the activities of these enzymes are reversed; HSL activity is increased, and LPL activity is decreased.

 

Option C. Increase in peripheral function of LDL receptors: Incorrect because LDL receptor function generally affects LDL levels, not directly influencing VLDL or triglyceride levels.

 

Option D. Increased in activity of hepatic lipase: Incorrect for this context as hepatic lipase primarily affects the metabolism of HDL and to a lesser extent LDL, not directly impacting TG and VLDL levels in the way described for this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


In chronic diabetes, the combination of increased hormone sensitive lipase activity (due to low insulin levels) and decreased lipoprotein lipase activity leads to higher levels of triglycerides and VLDL. This reflects the central role of insulin in lipid metabolism regulation.

questions.text: Identify the most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Subhepatic space

 

  1. The right subhepatic space is a deep space located in Rutherford Morison's pouch between the liver, transverse colon, and hepatic flexure. It is a common site of intra-abdominal abscess (second to pelvis).
  2. Abscesses in the right subhepatic space may occur due to conditions such as appendicitis, cholecystitis, perforated duodenal ulcer, or as a complication of upper abdominal surgery.
    • Also known as Rutherford Morison's pouch, the subhepatic space is situated between the liver's posterior surface and the right kidney's anterior surface.
    • It's a potential space that can collect fluid or pus.
    • It is a common site for abscess formation, especially after conditions like appendicitis, where the infection can spread upwards into this space.
    • Due to its anatomical location and the potential for infections like appendicitis to spread to this region, the subhepatic space is recognized as the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peri splenic space: The peri-splenic space is located around the spleen and is bounded by the diaphragm, stomach, and the splenic flexure of the colon. Abscesses in this space can arise from a splenic infection or trauma, but it is not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses.

 

Option B. Left subphrenic space: The left subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the spleen/stomach. It's a potential space for abscess formation, especially after splenic surgeries or gastric surgeries. However, it's not the most common site for intra-abdominal abscesses compared to the right side.

 

Option C. Right subphrenic space: The right subphrenic space is located between the diaphragm and the liver. Abscesses in this space can arise due to infections that spread from the liver or gallbladder, or after surgeries involving these organs. It is one of the potential sites for abscess formation, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common site of an intra-abdominal abscess is subhepatic space.

choices.text: Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition
Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis
Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition
Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol

questions.text: Identify the wrongly matched pair of antifungals with its mechanism of action? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Flucytosine: Inhibits microtubule synthesis and thus hinders mitosis

 

All of the above Antifungal agents are correctly matched with their corresponding mechanisms of action except for Flucytosine. Flucytosine acts by inhibiting the synthesis of nucleic acid. Griseofulvin is the antifungal that acts by inhibiting microtubule synthesis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ketoconazole: Lanosterol-14-demethylase inhibition

Ketoconazole is correctly matched. It inhibits lanosterol-14-demethylase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol, which is a crucial component of the fungal cell membrane.

 

Option C. Terbinafine: Squalene epoxidase inhibition

Terbinafine is correctly matched. It inhibits squalene epoxidase, an enzyme involved in the biosynthesis of ergosterol, leading to the accumulation of toxic levels of squalene and cell death.

 

Option D. Amphotericin B: Sequesters ergosterol

Amphotericin B is correctly matched. It binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that increase membrane permeability and cause cell contents to leak out, leading to cell death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flucytosine inhibits nucleic acid synthesis, not microtubule synthesis. The correct antifungal that inhibits microtubule synthesis is griseofulvin.

choices.text: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) with aortic regurgitation
Coronary arteriovenous (AV) fistula
Pulmonary AV fistula

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a continuous murmur that is audible throughout both systole and diastole. On further examination, the murmur is noted to be loudest at the second intercostal space along the left sternal border. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause this type of murmur? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: a. Ventricular septal defect (VSD) with aortic regurgitation

 

Explanation:

 

Continuous murmurs are typically caused by conditions that create a persistent pressure gradient between two chambers or vessels during both systole and diastole. Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation generally produces a pansystolic and early diastolic murmur rather than a continuous murmur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coronary AV fistula: This condition causes a continuous murmur due to the persistent blood flow from a high-pressure coronary artery to a low-pressure cardiac chamber or vein throughout the cardiac cycle.

 

Option B. Pulmonary AV fistula: This condition results in a continuous murmur as blood flows continuously between the pulmonary artery and vein.

 

Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA): A PDA produces a continuous murmur due to the ongoing flow of blood from the aorta to the pulmonary artery during both systole and diastole.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand that continuous murmurs arise from a persistent pressure difference across a cardiac structure throughout the cardiac cycle, distinguishing them from murmurs that occur only during specific phases

questions.text: A pediatric patient is brought to the emergency department with signs of ocular hypotension and apnea. The parents are concerned about the child's condition and have provided a history of recent medication use. It is crucial to determine which drug may have caused these symptoms in the infant. Drug capable of causing ocular hypotension with apnea in infants is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used to lower intraocular pressure in conditions such as glaucoma. It acts by decreasing the production of aqueous humor and increasing its outflow, thereby reducing intraocular pressure. While brimonidine is generally well-tolerated, it can have systemic side effects, particularly in infants. The most concerning systemic side effect in this context is central nervous system depression, which can manifest as symptoms like apnea (temporary cessation of breathing). Infants, especially premature ones, are more susceptible to such side effects. Therefore, brimonidine is the drug most likely responsible for causing ocular hypotension with apnea in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a beta-blocker commonly used to lower intraocular pressure. While it can have systemic side effects, including bradycardia and bronchospasm, it is not typically associated with apnea in infants.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the outflow of aqueous humor. It can cause side effects such as changes in iris color and eyelash growth. However, it is not known to cause apnea in infants.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used in ophthalmology to reduce intraocular pressure. While it can cause ocular hypotension, it is not a common cause of apnea, especially in infants.

questions.text: What is the most common route of the spread of retinoblastoma? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Direct invasion

 

Direct invasion is the most common mode of spread of retinoblastoma.

Direct invasion included the optic nerve and the other parts in contact with the tumour mass. Thus, Direct invasion is a better choice. 

 

  • Retinoblastoma is a malignancy that arises from the neurosensory retina.
  • It is the most common primary intraocular cancer in children.
  • Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei and scanty cytoplasm.

 

There are four types of retinoblastomas:

 

  1. Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye
  2. Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment
  3. Mixed type
  4. Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated.

 

The child is usually brought to the surgeon on account of a peculiar yellowish-white reflex from the pupil, sometimes called leukocoria or amaurotic cat's eye.

 

 

Other modes of presentation include a convergent or divergent squint, cataract, buphthalmos, hypopyon, or proptosis.

 

If left untreated, retinoblastoma runs through the following stages:

 

  • The quiescent stage: lasting from 6 months to a year.
  • The glaucomatous stage: results in enlargement of the globe, with apparent or real proptosis. Pain is severe during this stage but is relieved when the tumor bursts through the sclera.
  • The stage of extraocular extension
  • The stage of metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Optic nerve invasion: While possible, it is not the most common initial route of spread but is critical once involved, as it facilitates spread to the brain.

 

Option B. Hematogenous: Represents the method for distant metastasis rather than initial local spread.

 

Option D. Lymphatic spread: Uncommon in retinoblastoma since the eye lacks significant lymphatic channels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Direct invasion is the primary method of spread for retinoblastoma is essential in recognizing how the tumor progresses and impacts surrounding ocular structures. This knowledge is crucial for effective screening, early diagnosis, and management to prevent advanced stages of disease and potential metastasis.

questions.text: An affected male does not have affected children but an affected female always has affected children. Type of inheritance? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mitochondrial

 

A person mitochondrial genome is completely derived from the mother as sperm contain relatively few mitochondria which are degraded after fertilization. Thus, the mitochondrial inheritance is essentially maternal inheritance.

 

Mitochondrial genetic disorder can affect either sex, but males cannot transmit the disease to offspring.

 

 

Here are some examples of mitochondrial inheritance:

 

  1. Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON): This is a rare genetic disorder that affects the optic nerve and can cause vision loss due small fibres papulomacular bundles dropouts.
  2. Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes (MELAS): MELAS can be inherited from the mother, but it can also occur sporadically due to new mutations in the mtDNA.
  3. Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers (MERRF): This is a rare condition that causes seizures, muscle weakness, and other symptoms.
  4. Kearns-Sayre syndrome (KSS): This is a rare condition that affects multiple systems in the body, including the eyes (CPEO), heart (Heart blocks), and muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mitochondrial inheritance is characterized by the transmission of genetic traits solely through the maternal line, where affected females pass the condition to all of their offspring, while affected males do not pass it on to their children

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations is used to diagnose unicornuate uterus?  (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Falloposcopy
  2. Laparoscopy
  3. HSG
  4. X-ray
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

2. Laparoscopy: This is a minimally invasive surgical procedure that allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, including the uterus. It is effective in diagnosing structural anomalies like a unicornuate uterus.

 

3. HSG (Hysterosalpingogram): This is an X-ray procedure where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes. It helps in visualizing the shape of the uterine cavity and the patency of the fallopian tubes, making it useful in diagnosing a unicornuate uterus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 2, 4: While laparoscopy (2) is correct, X-ray (4) alone is not specific or detailed enough to diagnose a unicornuate uterus.

 

Option B. 1, 2: Falloposcopy (1) is used to visualize the interior of the fallopian tubes, not to diagnose uterine anomalies. Laparoscopy (2) is correct but falloposcopy is not appropriate for this diagnosis.

 

Option C. 1, 3: Similar to option B, falloposcopy (1) is not relevant for diagnosing uterine anomalies, even though HSG (3) is correct.

 

  • Falloposcopy: Refers to the visualization of the interior of the fallopian tube lumen and tubal ostia using a flexible fiber optic device via hysteroscope.
  • Diagnosis of Mullerian Anomalies: Can be achieved through various methods, including:
    1. Ultrasound (Preferably 3D USG)
    2. MRI (Investigation of choice)
    3. HSG
    4. Hystero-laparoscopy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopy and HSG are effective diagnostic tools for identifying unicornuate uterus and other Mullerian anomalies.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Pg 47, William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg418

questions.text: A preterm infant in the NICU was observed to have marked nasal flare, distinct xiphoid retractions, minimal intercostal retractions, and inspiratory lag with an audible grunt without a stethoscope. What would be the Silverman Anderson score? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is a clinical scoring system used to assess the degree of respiratory distress in neonates, particularly those with hyaline membrane disease (HMD) or other forms of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). The score ranges from 0 to 10, with higher scores indicating more severe respiratory distress.

 

The score is based on five parameters, each scored from 0 to 2:

 

1. Nasal Flaring:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

In this case, the infant has marked nasal flaring (score = 2).

 

2. Xiphoid Retractions (Substernal Retractions):

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Distinct

 

The infant has distinct xiphoid retractions (score = 2).

 

3. Intercostal Retractions:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Minimal
  • 2: Marked

 

The infant has minimal intercostal retractions (score = 1).

 

4. Chest Movement (Synchrony of Chest and Abdomen):

  • 0: Synchrony
  • 1: Lag on inspiration
  • 2: See-saw movement

 

The infant has inspiratory lag (score = 1).

 

5. Grunting:

  • 0: None
  • 1: Audible with stethoscope
  • 2: Audible without stethoscope

 

The infant has an audible grunt (score = 2).

 

Calculation:

 

  • Nasal Flaring: 2
  • Xiphoid Retractions: 2
  • Intercostal Retractions: 1
  • Chest Movement: 1
  • Grunting: 2

 

Total Score = 2 + 2 + 1 + 1 + 2 = 8

 

The correct Silverman-Anderson score for this infant would be 8.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Silverman-Anderson score is used to assess the severity of respiratory distress in neonates, with a score of 8 indicating significant distress requiring close monitoring and possibly intervention.

choices.text: Transverse perineal muscles
Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves

questions.text: All of the following structures are cut in mediolateral episiotomy except? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Obturator muscle

 

Explanation:

 

The obturator muscle is not cut in a mediolateral episiotomy. It is located deeper in the pelvis and is not involved in the incision made during this procedure.

 

Structures cut in a mediolateral episiotomy:

 

  • Posterior vaginal wall mucosa
  • Perineal muscles:
    • Superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles
    • Bulbospongiosus
    • Part of levator ani
  • Subcutaneous tissue and skin

 

Other options:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, the following structures are typically cut to facilitate childbirth:

 

Option A. Transverse perineal muscles: These include the superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles.

 

Option C. Bulbospongiosus: A muscle of the perineum that is also incised during the procedure.

 

Option D. Transverse perineal branches of pudendal nerves: These branches can be affected during the episiotomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a mediolateral episiotomy, various perineal structures, including the posterior vaginal wall mucosa, superficial and deep transverse perineal muscles, bulbospongiosus, part of the levator ani, subcutaneous tissue, and skin, are incised. The obturator muscle is not involved in this procedure.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Pg 649

questions.text: Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in which condition? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infective endocarditis

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are seen in infective endocarditis.

 

The aortic and mitral valves are the most commonly affected, but the right heart valves may also be involved in some cases.

 

Vegetations can be single or multiple, with one or more valves involved. Embolization is common and, due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli, can result in septic infarctions or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgment.

 

Other Options:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves are a hallmark of infective endocarditis, characterized by the presence of bacterial colonies and significant inflammatory response.

 

Subacute Bacterial Endocarditis shows small, friable vegetations.

questions.text: In a middle-aged diabetic patient with chronic kidney disease stage 5, which of the following drugs can be given safely without altering the dose? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Linagliptin

 

The gliptins are DPP4 inhibitors used in the management of type 2 DM. They are eliminated through the kidneys and are therefore contraindicated in patients with CKD. Only Linagliptin can be safely administered in such cases, as it is eliminated through the hepatobiliary system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vildagliptin: Vildagliptin is excreted primarily through the kidneys. In patients with severe renal impairment (CKD stage 5), dose adjustments are necessary to avoid drug accumulation and toxicity.

 

Option C. Saxagliptin: Saxagliptin also undergoes significant renal excretion. Therefore, it requires dose adjustments in patients with severe renal impairment to ensure safe and effective use.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Similar to vildagliptin and saxagliptin, sitagliptin is primarily excreted by the kidneys. Dose adjustments are necessary in patients with advanced CKD to avoid the risk of adverse effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Linagliptin can be safely administered to patients with chronic kidney disease stage 5 without the need for dose adjustments due to its unique hepatobiliary excretion pathway, making it the preferred DPP-4 inhibitor in such cases.

questions.text: Below is an electron microscopy depiction of a cellular structure. Determine the type of cell being depicted. (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hairy cell

 

Hairy cells are seen in Hairy cell leukemia. It is a B-cell tumor. Peripheral smear shows pancytopenia; hairy cells. Flow cytometry shows CD11/25/103 + cells. Annexin –A is the best marker.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Target cell: can be seen in thalassemia, hepatic disease with jaundice, hemoglobin C disorders, and the post splenectomy state.

 

 

Option C. Gaucher cell: is found in Gaucher’s disease which occurs due to absence of beta glucocerebrosidase enzyme.

 

 

Option D. Sickle cells:  are seen in sickle cell anemia. HbS has altered solubility and high chance of polymer formation especially with dehydration or hypoxemia causing alteration in shape. On rehydration, it is reversible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hairy cells are seen in hairy cell leukemia, characterized by B lymphocytes with hair-like projections, and are identified using electron microscopy and specific markers like CD11c, CD25, CD103, and Annexin-A.

choices.text: Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv
CT is the initial investigation for gallstones

questions.text: Identify the correct statement: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HU of water is zero

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) is a measure of radiodensity used in computed tomography (CT) scanning. By definition, the HU of water is zero, and this value serves as the reference point for measuring the density of other tissues. Values greater than zero indicate substances denser than water (e.g., bone, contrast material), while values less than zero indicate less dense substances (e.g., fat, air).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CT uses non-filtered X-rays: This statement is incorrect. CT scans use filtered X-rays to remove low-energy X-rays that would not contribute to image formation but would increase patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. Radiation exposure in CT scan is 20mSv: This is incorrect. Typical radiation doses for CT scans vary based on the body part being imaged. A head CT scan, for instance, typically involves a radiation dose of around 2 mSv, while an abdominal CT scan might be around 5 mSv. A dose of 20 mSv would be exceedingly high for a single CT scan.

 

Option C. CT is the initial investigation for gallstones: This is incorrect. Ultrasound is the initial investigation of choice for gallstones due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and lack of ionizing radiation. CT is more commonly used for other types of stones, such as kidney stones.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Hounsfield Unit (HU) of water is zero, serving as a reference point for measuring the radiodensity of various tissues in CT imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to store blood for up to 35 days? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Citrate phosphate dextrose adenine – 1

 

Citrate-phosphate-dextrose solution with adenine (CPDA) is an anticoagulant and preservative for storage of blood. It can prolong red blood cell storage life up to 35 days. It maintains platelet viability. Usage of CPDA improves post-transfusion visibility and improves glucose and ATP levels in blood. CPDA can increase serum uric acid levels (due to adenine component).

 

The shelf life of storage of other options:

 

  • Acid Citrate dextrose - 21 days
  • Citrate-phosphate dextrose - 21 days
  • Citrate Phosphate 2 Dextrose (CP2D): 21 days

 

Educational Objective:

 

Citrate Phosphate Dextrose Adenine (CPDA-1) can be used to store blood for up to 35 days, making it the solution with the longest preservation capability among the options provided.

questions.text: A Mediterranean person receive primaquine. Which pathway is affected by G-6-PD enzyme deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) HMP pathway

 

This is the correct pathway affected by G6PD enzyme deficiency. G6PD is an enzyme crucial for the proper functioning of the HMP pathway. Deficiency in G6PD can lead to hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells) in response to oxidative stress, as the HMP pathway is responsible for generating reducing equivalents (NADPH) necessary to protect cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glycolysis: G6PD deficiency primarily affects the HMP pathway, not glycolysis. Glycolysis is a separate metabolic pathway involved in the breakdown of glucose for energy production.

 

Option C. Gluconeogenesis: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect gluconeogenesis. Gluconeogenesis is the metabolic pathway responsible for producing glucose from non-carbohydrate sources, and it does not rely on the G6PD enzyme.

 

Option D. Krebs cycle: G6PD deficiency does not directly affect the Krebs cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle or TCA cycle). The Krebs cycle is involved in the oxidative metabolism of acetyl-CoA, and G6PD deficiency primarily impacts the earlier steps of glucose metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

G6PD is the first and rate limiting enzyme of HMP pathway which is the major source of NADPH that is required for reduced glutathione generation and help reduce oxidative stress by neutralizing free radicals.

 

Primaquine is an antimalarial drug and causes oxidative stress. In patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, primaquine can cause hemolysis so it is avoided.

 

Reference: Harper’s 31st ed/pg- 182

questions.text: A 65-year-old man suffering from persistent fatigue and lymph node enlargement visits the outpatient department. Examination of his peripheral smear reveals the presence of smudge cells. To further establish a diagnosis, what additional investigations will you conduct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Flow cytometry

 

An elderly man presenting with chronic fatigue and lymphadenopathy and revelation of smudge cells on peripheral smear suggests a diagnosis of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia. Flow cytometry is the investigation of choice.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR is typically used for detecting specific genetic mutations or translocations but is not the primary diagnostic tool for CLL.

 

Option B. Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH): FISH is used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities, such as deletions or translocations. While useful, it is not the first-line investigation for diagnosing CLL.

 

Option D. Cytogenetics: Cytogenetic analysis can reveal chromosomal abnormalities associated with CLL, such as deletion 13q, but is typically used in conjunction with other tests like flow cytometry.

 

Educational Objective:


Flow cytometry is the primary diagnostic tool for confirming Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, particularly in cases where smudge cells are identified on a peripheral smear.

choices.text: Transfusion reaction
Acute adrenal crisis
Fat embolism

questions.text: A 24-year-old man met with an road traffic accident and was brought to the casualty after 6 hours. His B.P. was 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate was 110/min, and Sp02 was 92%. A blood transfusion was done. After a few hours, the patient is febrile, tachypneic, and starts bleeding from the IV and NG tube sites. His SpO2 levels started falling. What could be the cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transfusion reaction

 

Given the clinical scenario the most likely diagnosis is acute hemolytic transfusion reaction causing DIC (disseminated intravascular coagulation) resulting in bleeding from IV catheter and nasogastric tube within a few hours of blood transfusion.

 

Acute Hemolytic Transfusion reaction

 

  • Immune-mediated hemolysis
  • Preformed antibodies in recipient lyse donor erythrocytes.
  • Complement-mediated lysis occurs causing intravascular hemolysis and hemoglobinuria.
  • Severe cases, tissue factor released from the lysed erythrocytes may initiate DIC, which is a consumptive coagulopathy with bleeding manifestations.
  • Other complications include shock, acute kidney injury, and sometimes, death.

 

The various blood transfusion reactions according to their time of occurrence are as follows:

 

  • Anaphylactic reaction - Within a few seconds to minutes of the transfusion. Common in selective IgA deficiency patients.
  • Allergic/Urticarial reactions - Within 2-3 hours of transfusion
  • Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) - Within 24 hours of transfusion
  • Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction (FNHT) - Within 6 hours of transfusion
  • Delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction (DHTR) - After 24 hours of transfusion


TRALI vs TACO:

 

 

TRALI: transfusion-related acute lung injury, TACO: Transfusion-associated cardiac overload, CXR: chest X-ray, BNP: B type natriuretic peptide, PAOP: pulmonary artery occluding pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute adrenal crisis: This condition involves sudden adrenal insufficiency, leading to hypotension, shock, and electrolyte imbalances. It would not typically cause the specific symptoms of hemolysis and DIC seen in this case.

 

Option C. Fat embolism: Fat embolism syndrome can occur after long bone fractures, presenting with respiratory distress, neurological symptoms, and petechiae. However, it typically occurs within 24-72 hours after injury and is not directly associated with blood transfusions.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock: Hemorrhagic shock results from significant blood loss, leading to hypotension and tachycardia. While this could be a consideration, the transfusion reaction and subsequent DIC better explain the patient's clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) can lead to disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), characterized by rapid onset of fever, bleeding from multiple sites, and hemolysis shortly after a blood transfusion.

questions.text:
True statement regarding the administration of 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors is/are: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Reduces dihydrotestosterone levels

 

2. Reduces testosterone levels

 

3. Elevates PSA levels

 

4. Decreases PSA levels
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 4

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, are used primarily in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and conditions like male pattern baldness and hirsutism. These medications work by inhibiting the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase, which is responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent androgen.

 

Effects of 5 Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors

 

  1. Reduces Dihydrotestosterone Levels: By inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT, these drugs significantly lower DHT levels in the body. DHT is a key factor in the development and enlargement of the prostate and also contributes to hair loss.
  1. Decreases PSA Levels: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are often reduced as a result of decreased prostate volume and reduced androgenic stimulation of the prostate. PSA is a marker used to screen for and monitor prostate cancer and other prostate-related conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Reduces Testosterone Levels: This statement is incorrect. 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors do not significantly reduce testosterone levels. In fact, due to the reduced conversion to DHT, plasma testosterone levels may remain unchanged or even increase slightly.
  2. Elevates PSA Levels: This statement is incorrect. These drugs typically decrease PSA levels due to reduced androgenic activity in the prostate.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Uses: These inhibitors are used alongside surgery and alpha-1 adrenergic blockers for treating BPH. They are also utilized in managing male pattern baldness and hirsutism.
  • Mechanism of Action: By competitively inhibiting 5 alpha-reductase, they reduce the production of DHT, which is responsible for stimulating prostate growth and hair loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are the competitive inhibitors of the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active dihydroxy testosterone (DHT). This enzyme inhibition results in:

 

 

  • Decreased DHT levels
  • Decreased PSA levels
  • Reduces prostate volume
  • However, plasma testosterone levels remain unchanged or may increase due to non-conversion to DHT.

choices.text: Ileocolic, right colic and branch of middle colic
Ileocolic, right colic, stem of middle colic, left colic
Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient has been diagnosed with proximal transverse colon carcinoma. The physician recommends an extended right colectomy as a treatment option. Which arteries should be resected during an extended right colectomy to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
