Ans. C) Ileocolic, right colic and trunk of middle colic.

 

During an extended right colectomy, the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of the middle colic vessels are typically resected to prevent the spread of cancer in proximal transverse colon carcinoma.

 

The stem of the middle colic and the left colic artery are not resected during an extended right colectomy as they are not directly involved with the blood supply to the proximal transverse colon. It is important to note that the surgical management of colon cancer depends on the stage and location of the tumor and may involve various surgical techniques, including colectomy and lymphadenectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of radical colectomies and vessels ligated:

 

  1. Right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and right branch of middle colic artery
  2. Extended right hemicolectomy: Ileocolic, right colic and stem/origin of middle colic artery
  3. Left hemicolectomy: Left colic and sigmoid artery

choices.text: Urea breath test
Serological test for H. pylori antibodies
Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy
Fecal occult blood test (FOBT)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of peptic ulcer disease presents to the clinic for follow-up after completing a 14-day course of triple therapy with omeprazole, amoxicillin, and clarithromycin for H. pylori eradication. His initial symptoms included epigastric pain, bloating, and nausea, which have resolved since completing the treatment. He has no current complaints and feels significantly better. On examination, his abdomen is soft, non-tender, and without organomegaly. The patient wants to ensure that the infection has been completely eradicated to prevent recurrence. Which test is the most appropriate to confirm the success of H. pylori eradication therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: mA. Urea breath test

 

Explanation:

 

Helicobacter pylori is a Gram-negative, urease-producing bacterium that is a major cause of peptic ulcer disease, gastric mucosa-associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma, and gastric adenocarcinoma. The diagnosis of H. pylori infection can be made using both invasive and non-invasive tests. Non-invasive methods include the urea breath test, stool antigen test, and serological tests. Invasive methods involve endoscopy with biopsy, where a biopsy urease test, histological examination, or culture can be performed to diagnose the infection and determine antibiotic resistance. The commonly used eradication regimen involves triple therapy, including a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) like omeprazole, combined with two antibiotics, typically amoxicillin and clarithromycin, administered for 14 days. After completing treatment, a PPI is often continued for an additional 30 days to promote ulcer healing. The urea breath test is the preferred method for confirming eradication as it directly measures active infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Serological test for H. pylori antibodies
Serological tests detect antibodies against H. pylori, indicating exposure to the bacterium. However, these antibodies can persist for months or even years after successful eradication, making serological testing unreliable for assessing the success of treatment.

 

Option C. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy with biopsy
Endoscopy with biopsy can directly visualize the gastric mucosa and allow for biopsy urease testing and histology. However, it is invasive and generally reserved for cases with severe symptoms, atypical presentations, or suspicion of malignancy. It is not routinely used for post-treatment confirmation.

 

Option D. Fecal occult blood test (FOBT)
FOBT is used to detect gastrointestinal bleeding, often for colorectal cancer screening, but does not provide information about H. pylori status or eradication. It has no role in confirming the success of H. pylori eradication therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Helicobacter pylori is a Gram-negative, urease-producing bacterium linked to peptic ulcer disease, gastric lymphoma, and adenocarcinoma. Eradication can be confirmed using non-invasive tests like the urea breath test or stool antigen test, which are highly sensitive and specific. Serological tests are not useful post-treatment due to persistent antibodies, and endoscopy is reserved for complex or atypical cases. Proper test timing post-therapy is critical to avoid false-negative results.

questions.text: What among the options serves as a factor that conditions to the development of malnutrition? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Infectious diseases

 

Infectious diseases act as conditioning influences that contribute to the development of malnutrition. They can exacerbate malnutrition by increasing morbidity, leading to decreased food intake, loss of nutrients, anorexia, and overall growth failure, which in turn lowers immunity and creates a vicious cycle of poor health.

 

Other 3 Options are not considered as a conditioning influence.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

choices.text: The assertion is independently a true statement, but the reasons is independently a false statement.
The assertion is independently a false statement, but the reasons is independently a true statement.
Both assertion and reason are true statements
Both assertion and reason are false statements

questions.text:
Assertion: Resting membrane potential is dependent on proteins and phosphate ions.

 

Reason: Diffusion potential can be calculated using Nernst Equation. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both assertion and reason are true statements

 

Resting membrane potential refers to the electrical charge difference across the cell membrane of a neuron or other excitable cells when the cell is at rest, meaning it is not actively transmitting signals. This potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions, across the cell membrane.

 

Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

 

 

Where:

 

  • E is the equilibrium potential for the ion.
  • R is the ideal gas constant.
  • T is the absolute temperature (in Kelvin).
  • z is the valence (charge) of the ion.
  • F is Faraday's constant.
  • [Cout]​ and [Cin]​ are the concentrations of the ion outside and inside the membrane, respectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Resting membrane potential is maintained by the uneven distribution of ions, primarily sodium (Na+), potassium (K+), chloride (Cl-), and other negative ions (including proteins and phosphate ions), across the cell membrane.
  • The Nernst equation is used to calculate the diffusion potential (also known as the equilibrium potential) for a specific ion across a semi-permeable membrane.

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome (ACS)

questions.text: A 65-year-old postmenopausal woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset chest pain and shortness of breath that started shortly after attending her husband's funeral. She has no significant past medical history and was previously in good health. On examination, her blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Her ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior leads, suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome. However, coronary angiography reveals normal coronary arteries without any significant blockages. Echocardiography shows apical ballooning of the left ventricle with hypercontractility of the basal segments. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Takotsubo cardiomyopathy

 

Explanation:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as stress-induced cardiomyopathy or "broken heart syndrome," is commonly seen in postmenopausal women who experience sudden emotional or physical stress, such as the loss of a loved one. This condition is characterized by transient left ventricular dysfunction, often manifesting as apical ballooning with hypercontractility of the basal segments. ECG findings can mimic an acute coronary syndrome, with ST-segment elevation and T-wave inversions, but coronary angiography typically shows no significant coronary artery blockages. The pathophysiology involves neurogenic myocardial stunning primarily due to excessive catecholamine release, which affects myocardial contractility. Patients often present with mild troponin elevation and regional wall motion abnormalities that do not correspond to a single coronary artery territory. Management involves supportive care, including beta-blockers and ACE inhibitors, with a generally good prognosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute coronary syndrome (ACS): Although the ECG changes suggest ACS, this diagnosis is less likely due to the absence of significant coronary artery disease on angiography and the presence of characteristic apical ballooning on echocardiography, which is typical for Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

 

Option B. Pericarditis: Pericarditis can present with chest pain and ECG changes, but it is usually associated with diffuse ST-segment elevation without localized wall motion abnormalities or apical ballooning. It is not characterized by the findings seen on echocardiography or coronary angiography.

 

Option D. Myocarditis: Myocarditis can cause chest pain, ECG changes, and wall motion abnormalities but often presents with global left ventricular dysfunction rather than the distinct pattern of apical ballooning seen in Takotsubo cardiomyopathy. Additionally, coronary arteries are usually normal, but myocarditis is typically confirmed with cardiac MRI or biopsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is a transient cardiac condition often triggered by acute emotional or physical stress, predominantly affecting postmenopausal women. It mimics acute coronary syndrome on ECG, with distinct echocardiographic findings of apical ballooning and normal coronary arteries on angiography. The condition typically has a good prognosis with appropriate management.

questions.text: Vessel A has a length of L and diameter of D and vessel B has 2L and 2D. Considering, the flow is laminar through both the cylinders, the flow through B is how many times as much as the flow through A? (INICETMAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8 times

 

Flow through B will be 8 times more than the flow through A.

According to Poiseuille Hagen formula,

 

F= AP X π/8 x 1/n x r/L

F= flow

AP = pressure difference between two ends of the tube

П = viscosity

r-radius of the tube

L-length of the tube

Hence flow directly varies to the 4th power of radius and inversely varies to length.

 

Flow through B = (2r)4/2L = 2*2*2*2/ 2 = 16/2= 8 times

 

Educational Objective:

 

The flow is directly proportional to the fourth power of the radius (𝑟4r4) and inversely proportional to the length (𝐿L) of the vessel.

questions.text: The presence of a pearly white papule on the mother's forehead, which is also seen in her infant, can be due to which of the following virus? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pox virus

 

The above image shows shiny, pearly white, umbilicated papules which are suggestive of molluscum contagiosum. It’s a DNA virus.

 

  • It is mainly caused by Pox virus which is a DNA virus.
  • Virus: Molluscum Contagiosum Virus (MCV).
    • MCV-1: Children over Face (Not seen over palms & soles).
    • MCV-2: Adults producing lesions over Genitals.
  • Microscopic examination - Lesions shows eosinophilic inclusions called Henderson-Patterson bodies.
  • Transmission: Skin to skin contact.

 

Note: Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Usually, it is self-limiting and will disappear by itself. Thus, there is no need for treatment.
  • Destruction with cantharidin, trichloroacetic acid, diluted liquefied phenol, or surgical removal are a few options.

 

Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon: New lesions develop along the line of trauma due to Autoinoculation.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. HPV (Human Papilloma Virus) leads to warts, but the lesions are typically rough-surfaced as shown in the image below, rather than pearly.

 

 

  • Option C. Adenovirus does not typically cause visible skin manifestations like the one shown.
  • Option D. Herpes virus causes vesicular and ulcerative lesions as shown in the image below, rather than pearly papules.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of pearly white papules in both a mother and her infant is indicative of molluscum contagiosum, a skin infection caused by a Poxvirus.

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I, Chapter 25, Page no 25.12-14

questions.text: All of the following are responsible for Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) INF- y  

 

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR) is associated with a transient, marked rise in circulating tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF alpha), interleukin 6 (IL-6) and interleukin 8 (IL-8).

 

It is an inflammatory reaction that can occur after treatment for syphilis.

 

The symptoms usually begin 2 hours from the administration of the antibiotic and resolve within 24 hours.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TNF alpha: Directly involved in the inflammatory response associated with JHR.

 

Option B. IL-6: Also directly involved in JHR, promoting inflammatory processes.

 

Option C. IL-8: Plays a role in recruiting neutrophils to sites of infection, contributing to the inflammatory reaction in JHR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is primarily driven by a surge in pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF alpha, IL-6, and IL-8, but not by INF-γ.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is mainly responsible for the resorption of divalent ions? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Paracellular Transport

 

Paracellular Transport in the thick ascending limb of loop of Henle is responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as, calcium, magnesium, etc.

 

The sodium-potassium ATPase pump in the basolateral cell membrane maintains a low intracellular sodium concentration and a negative electrical potential in the cell.

 

The 1-sodium, 2-chloride, 1-potassium co-transporter in the luminal membrane transports these three ions from the tubular lumen into the cells, using the potential energy released by diffusion of sodium down an electrochemical gradient into the cells.

 

Sodium is also transported into the tubular cell by sodium-hydrogen counter-transport.

 

The positive charge (+8 mV) due to slight back leak of potassium ions into the lumen of the tubular lumen relative to the interstitial fluid forces cations such as Mg++ and Ca++ to diffuse from the lumen to the interstitial fluid via the paracellular pathway.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active: Incorrect. This involves direct use of ATP for ion transport, not the main mechanism for divalent ion resorption in the thick ascending limb.

 

Option B. Secondary Active: Incorrect. While secondary active transport is important for moving ions, it is not the primary mechanism for divalent ion resorption here.

 

Option D. Transcellular Transport: Incorrect. Transcellular transport involves movement through the cell, whereas divalent ion resorption primarily occurs via the paracellular pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paracellular transport in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is the main mechanism responsible for the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium, driven by the positive luminal charge and facilitated by the sodium-potassium ATPase pump and co-transporters.

choices.text: His 48-year-old HLA-matched sister who is blood type A negative and in good health
An unrelated donor who is blood type O negative and HLA-matched at 9/10 loci
His 50-year-old HLA-identical brother who is blood type O positive and otherwise healthy
An unrelated donor who is a complete HLA match but has blood type B negative

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is being considered for an allogeneic stem cell transplant after unsuccessful chemotherapy treatment. He has blood type O negative and has undergone HLA typing as part of the transplant preparation. Several potential donors have been identified, including siblings and unrelated individuals, each with varying levels of compatibility. The goal is to choose the most suitable donor to enhance transplant success and minimize complications. Which donor would be the most suitable match?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. His 50-year-old HLA-identical brother who is blood type O positive and otherwise healthy

 

Explanation:

 

The most suitable donor for the patient is his HLA-identical brother, despite the minor blood type mismatch (O+ vs. O-). HLA-identical sibling donors are preferred due to their significantly lower risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) and better transplant outcomes. The minor Rh incompatibility (positive vs. negative) is generally manageable during the transplant process, with the advantages of an HLA-identical match outweighing this minor difference.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. His 48-year-old HLA-matched sister who is blood type A negative and in good health: Despite being HLA-matched, her blood type (A negative) is not compatible with the patient's O negative type, which can lead to complications during the transplant process.

 

Option B. An unrelated donor who is blood type O negative and HLA-matched at 9/10 loci: Although the blood type matches, the incomplete HLA match poses a higher risk of GVHD compared to a fully HLA-matched sibling, making this option less favorable.

 

Option D. An unrelated donor who is a complete HLA match but has blood type B negative: Even with a complete HLA match, the major blood type incompatibility (B vs. O) could complicate the transplant, making the HLA-identical sibling a better option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In allogeneic stem cell transplantation, the most suitable donor is typically an HLA-identical sibling, as this minimizes the risk of GVHD and optimizes transplant outcomes. While minor blood type mismatches can be managed, HLA compatibility remains the most critical factor, particularly in high-risk hematologic conditions such as AML. Sibling donors provide a balance of optimal HLA matching with manageable complications from minor blood type differences.

questions.text: The sensory area marked in the image is primarily innervated by which nerve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

 

The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

 

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

 

Option C. Median Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

 

  • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

choices.text: Components of MELD (Model for end stage liver disease) scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L).
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy.
Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR.
MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation.

questions.text: Which among the following is false? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Components of CTP (Child Turcotte Pugh) are creatinine, bilirubin, and INR

 

Statement C is false. The Child Turcotte Pugh (CTP) score does not include creatinine as a component. Instead, CTP uses the following parameters to assess the severity of liver disease: bilirubin, albumin, INR, ascites, and encephalopathy. This score is traditionally used to evaluate the prognosis in chronic liver disease, primarily cirrhosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Components of MELD scoring system are creatinine, bilirubin, INR, serum sodium (mEq/L): This statement is true. The MELD score has been updated to include serum sodium along with creatinine, bilirubin, and INR to improve its accuracy in predicting mortality risk in liver transplant candidates.

 

Option B. Components of CTP score are albumin, bilirubin, INR, ascites, encephalopathy: This is accurate and reflects the correct components of the CTP score.

 

Option D. MELD score is used to assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation: This is true. The MELD score is widely used to prioritize patients for liver transplantation based on their risk of death from liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MELD-Na components mnemonic “CBI”

 

C - Creatinine

B - Bilirubin

I - INR + Sodium

 

CTP score mnemonic BANANa

 

  • Bilirubin Albumin INR Ascites eNcephalopathy

 

Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chap 344

choices.text: Non-functioning pituitary adenoma
Pituitary stalk compression

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 9-month history of irregular menstrual cycles and persistent bilateral nipple discharge. She reports associated headaches and occasional blurred vision, particularly when looking to the sides. She denies any significant weight gain, medication use, or history of thyroid disease. On physical examination, there are no signs of hirsutism, and she has normal vital signs. Breast examination reveals non-bloody, milky discharge. Laboratory studies reveal a serum prolactin level of 260 µg/L. A brain MRI shows a 1.7 cm mass in the sella turcica with suprasellar extension but no invasion of the cavernous sinus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Prolactinoma

 

 

Explanation:

 

Prolactinoma is the most likely diagnosis given the markedly elevated prolactin level (>200 µg/L), clinical symptoms of galactorrhea, and menstrual irregularities, along with a pituitary mass on MRI. Prolactinomas are the most common type of functioning pituitary adenomas and are characterized by excessive secretion of prolactin, which inhibits gonadotropin-releasing hormone, leading to menstrual dysfunction and galactorrhea. The size and imaging features of the mass further support the diagnosis of a prolactinoma.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Non-functioning pituitary adenoma
Non-functioning pituitary adenomas can present with mass effects, such as headaches and visual disturbances, but they do not secrete prolactin or other hormones. Prolactin levels may be slightly elevated due to stalk effect but usually do not exceed 100-150 µg/L, distinguishing it from a functioning prolactinoma.

 

Option B. Pituitary stalk compression
Pituitary stalk compression can cause mild hyperprolactinemia due to reduced inhibitory dopamine delivery to the pituitary, but prolactin levels typically remain below 150 µg/L. This scenario is inconsistent with the significantly elevated prolactin level observed in the patient.

 

Option D. Drug-induced hyperprolactinemia
Certain drugs, such as antipsychotics, can increase prolactin levels by blocking dopamine receptors. However, these levels rarely exceed 100 µg/L and usually do not cause large pituitary masses on imaging. The absence of medication use in the patient’s history makes this diagnosis less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolactinomas are the most common pituitary adenomas and are characterized by prolactin levels typically greater than 200 µg/L, associated with symptoms like amenorrhea and galactorrhea. MRI is crucial for diagnosing the extent of the adenoma. Differentiating prolactinomas from other causes of hyperprolactinemia is essential for appropriate management, as these tumors often require dopamine agonists for treatment.

choices.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.
Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.
Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false?  (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

 

OSTEOPOROSIS

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • So, osteoporosis characteristically has normal calcium, phosphate and alkaline phosphatase levels.
  • Bone Mineral Density is measured by DEXA (Dual Emission X-ray Absorptiometry) Scan and it is matched to DEXA scan of 30-year-old individual of the same sex and T score is calculated.

 

 

  • Etiology of Osteoporosis:

 

 

  • Imaging:
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

X-ray of osteoporotic spine: Codfish vertebra

 

  • Singh’s Index is used for osteoporosis grading.
  • Treatment: Drugs used in osteoporosis are:
    1. Inhibit resorption: Bisphosphonates (drug of choice), Denosumab, calcitonin, estrogen, SERMS, gallium nitrate.
    2. Stimulate formation: Teriparatide (PTH analogue), calcium, calcitriol, fluorides.
    3. Both actions: Strontium ranelate
       
  • Bisphosphonases are not metabolized and are excreted intact in urine. Their t 1/2 is 1-10 years and cessation of treatment does not lead to rapid bone loss. These drugs decrease the incidence of vertebral and non vertebral fractures.
  • Prolonged used of Bisphosphonates has been reported with increased incidence of fractures of proximal femur. Hence, a patient on Bisphosphonates with hip pain requires X-rays to evaluate and diagnose these fractures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time. Teriparatide is a recombinant fragment of human parathyroid hormone. To preserve the increments of BMD acquired with teriparatide, therapy with an antiresorptive agent (e.g., bisphosphonates) should restart after teriparatide discontinuation. Bisphosphonates help retain BMD gains that tend to regress after cessation of teriparatide. Concomitant use with teriparatide is to be avoided because they may blunt its anabolic effect.

 

Option C. Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day. 1200 mg of calcium (total of diet and supplement) and 800 international units of vitamin D daily for postmenopausal osteoporosis are recommended.

 

Option D. Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium. Calcium and vitamin D supplementation is a necessary adjunct to all forms of anti-osteoporotic therapies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.
